fields.label: Client gave birth in the last 6 months
Breastfeeding
fields.label_info_text: Whether or not the client is currently breastfeeding.

fields.label: Breastfeeding status
fields.label_info_text:
Exclusive breastfeeding = Giving the infant only breast milk with no supplementation of any type - not even water - except for perhaps vitamins, minerals, or medication

Fully breastfeeding = The client is giving the infant breast milk almost exclusively but also water, juice, vitamins or other nutrients infrequently

Nearly fully breastfeeding = The client is giving the infant some liquid or food in addition to breast milk, but more than three-fourths (75%) of feedings are breastfeeds

Partially breastfeeding = The client is breastfeeding less than nearly fully breastfeeding, giving the infant more supplementation with other liquids or food. Less than three-fourths (75%) of feedings are breastfeeds.

fields.text: Counsel according to guidance provided in "Family Planning: A Global Handbook for Providers" or in accordance to national guidelines.

This is a sign and/or symptom of a serious health condition. This condition occurs rarely to extremely rarely among users of contraceptive methods and among people of reproductive age. Immediately take action or refer for care if a client reports this issue. Clients who develop this condition might need to switch methods.

fields.label: Keeping method
fields.label_info_text: Whether the client wishes to keep using their current method or stop the method or switch methods.

fields.label: How method removal is being done
fields.label_info_text: For clients needing an IUD or implant removal, whether the service is being provided on site or off-site (i.e. referral).

fields.text:
Good counselling helps clients choose and use family planning methods that suit them. Clients differ; their situations differ, and they need different kinds of help. The best counseling is tailored to the individual client. The essential elements include counselling the client on:
- What is the contraceptive method?
- How does the contraceptive method work?
- How effective is the contraceptive method?
- How is the contraceptive method used? / When do you take the contraceptive method?
- What are possible side effects or adverse events from the contraceptive method?
- What are the contraceptive method’s other benefits?
- Is the contraceptive method compatible with breastfeeding?
- Does the contraceptive method protect against STIs, HIV/AIDS?

fields.label: Method requested
fields.label_info_text: The first pick of method desired by the client, prior to medical eligibility tests. This may be the method in mind or the method selected after discussing the full range of methods.

Method Removal
Voluntary Informed Consent
Please obtain informed consent before proceeding with the method provision.
Exams & Tests
Pelvic/genital examination needed
fields.toaster_info_text: A pelvic/genital examination is Class A: Essential and mandatory in all circumstances for safe and effective use of the contraceptive method.

fields.text: Blood pressure screening needed
fields.toaster_info_text: A blood pressure screening is Class A: Essential and mandatory in all circumstances for safe and effective use of the contraceptive method.

fields.text: STI risk assessment: medical history and physical examination needed
fields.toaster_info_text: A STI risk assessment: medical history and physical examination is Class A: Essential and mandatory in all circumstances for safe and effective use of the contraceptive method.
fields.toaster_info_title: STI risk assessment: medical history and physical examination needed

fields.text: STI/HIV screening: laboratory tests needed
fields.toaster_info_text: A STI/HIV screening: laboratory tests is Class B: The examination or test contributes substantially to safe and effective use, but implementation may be considered within the public health and/or service context. The risk of not performing the examination or test should be balanced against the benefits of making the contraceptive method available, meaning they contributes substantially to safe and effective use.

fields.text: Haemoglobin test needed
fields.toaster_info_text: A haemoglobin test is Class B: The examination or test contributes substantially to safe and effective use, but implementation may be considered within the public health and/or service context. The risk of not performing the examination or test should be balanced against the benefits of making the contraceptive method available, meaning they contributes substantially to safe and effective use.

fields.text: Blood pressure screening needed
fields.toaster_info_text: In healthy women, no examinations or tests are essential or mandatory before initiating this method. However, there is special consideration for blood pressure screening; it is desirable to have blood pressure measurements taken before initiation of this method. It is important to note that in settings where blood pressure measurements are unavailable, women should not be denied use of this method simply because their blood pressure cannot be measured.

fields.text: Method at Exit

Cu-IUD
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.
- A Cu-IUD can be inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse as an emergency contraceptive.
- When the time of ovulation can be estimated, a Cu-IUD can be inserted beyond 5 days after intercourse, as long as insertion does not occur more than 5 days after ovulation.

LNG-IUD
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.

LNG-IUD
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- A backup method is required.
- Client must abstain from sex or use additional contraceptive protection for the next 7 days.

LNG-IUD
- The LNG-IUD should be inserted at least 6 days after the client has taken ECPs (progestin-only, combined, or ulipristal acetate (UPA)).
- A backup method is required.
- Client must abstain from sex or use additional contraceptive protection for the next 7 days.

LNG-IUD
- Provide LNG-IUD immediately after the delivery of the placenta.
- No backup method required.

LNG-IUD
- Provide method at the time in which the repeat injection would have been given.
- No backup method required.

Etonogestrel (ETG) one-rod or Levonorgestrel (LNG) two-rod
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.

Etonogestrel (ETG) one-rod or Levonorgestrel (LNG) two-rod
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- A backup method is required.
- Client must abstain from sex or use additional contraceptive protection for the next 7 days.

Etonogestrel (ETG) one-rod or Levonorgestrel (LNG) two-rod
- Provide implant on the same day as the client takes ECPs if they are combined or progestin-only pills. Also provide a backup method.
- If the client took a Ulipristal acetate (UPA) ECP, then wait to insert the implant on the 6th day or later after taking UPA-ECPs. In this case also schedule follow-up appointment to receive the implant.

Etonogestrel (ETG) one-rod or Levonorgestrel (LNG) two-rod
- Provide method at the time in which the repeat injection would have been given.
- No backup method required.

DMPA-IM or DMPA-SC or NET-EN
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.

DMPA-IM or DMPA-SC or NET-EN
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- A backup method is required.

DMPA-IM or DMPA-SC or NET-EN
- Provide injection on the same day as the client takes ECPs if they are combined or progestin-only pills. Also provide a backup method.
- If the client took a Ulipristal acetate (UPA) ECP, then wait to provide the injection on the 6th day or later after taking UPA-ECPs. In this case also schedule follow-up appointment to receive the injection.

POP
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- Provide up to 1 year's supply POPs with appropriate instructions on initiation.
- No backup method required.

POP
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- Provide up to 1 year's supply POPs with appropriate instructions on initiation.
- A backup method is required.

COCs or Combined patch or CVR
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- Provide up to 1 year's supply COCs, patches, or CVRs with appropriate instructions on initiation.
- No backup method required.

COCs or Combined patch or CVR
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- Provide up to 1 year's supply COCs, patches, or CVRs with appropriate instructions on initiation.
- A backup method is required.

PVR
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.

ECPs
- Provide pill(s) and guide client to take immediately

LAM:
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.

Condoms or Withdrawal
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.

Fertility awareness-based methods (FAB)
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- A backup method is required.

Male sterilization
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- A backup method is required for 3 months following the procedure.

Female sterilization
- Start the method at the client's convenience.
- No backup method required.
